article:
'Overdrafting' is the process of extracting groundwater beyond the safe yield or
equilibrium yield of the aquifer.

Since every groundwater basin recharges at a different rate depending upon
precipitation, vegetative cover and soil conservation practises, the quantity of
groundwater that can be safely pumped varies greatly among regions of the world
and even within provinces. Some aquifers require a very long time to recharge
and thus the process of overdrafting can have consequences of effectively drying
up certain sub-surface water supplies.


Aquifer drawdown or overdrafting and the pumping of fossil water may be a
contributing factor to sea-level rise.

Groundwater extractions are a popular means of supplying water to communities
and agricultural producers. Since water is a necessity to survival for all
living things, communities and agricultural producers are using various ways to
meet their water demands and groundwater extractions are one way this is being
accomplished. Proper conservation of water needs to be used to keep the balance
of water supply and demand in equilibrium. The only economical way to extract
ground water is by drilling water wells. Currently there are approximately
128,000 registered water wells in the state of Texas. A registered well is one
that is monitored and follows certain restrictions enforced by the water
district. However, there have been approximately 1,000,000 water wells drilled
over the past 100 years (par. 2). If this rate continues in the future, the
demand will be greater than the supply and the water tables and aquifers will
become lower or even depleted. There are seven major aquifers and sixteen minor
aquifers in the state of Texas. These aquifers are located under 75% of the
state (par. 1). Many natural springs and creeks have lost their water source
because groundwater extractions have reduced the amount of underground water
supply. If these extractions had not occurred, many springs and creeks would be
flowing today. As the water table drops it becomes more expensive. You must
drill deeper to reach the amount of water required to suit your needs. When the
cost of drilling is by the foot, a couple of feet can add up fast and become
expensive. The pump also has to push the water to ground level. For every gallon
of water in the pipe, there is over 8 pounds of pressure placed on the pump.
This means that the pump in the well will need to be able to produce extra
horsepower, which will result in a larger pump (par. 5). Therefore, extracting
the water from the aquifer will require additional electricity. Each mounted
system is made with many different thing put into it, as in, automatic controls,
backwashing features, switches, gauges and sample ports, and also functioning
packaged units. Instructions are always provided on a control panel to
critically measure operating numerical factors forming one of a set that defines
a system or sets the conditions of its operation. Prior to the design or
instillation of a ground water extraction and treatment system it is required to
determine the necessary actions to follow. Whether it is clean up or containment
is the remedial action is determined at the beginning of this process. If clean-
up is chosen the objectives are determined. If containment is chosen the ground
water extraction is used to establish a hydraulic barrier to prevent continued
migration or containment plumes.
